course: UBC 405 - Global Pathway Course - Social Sciences
description: UBC 405TUT - Global Pathway Course - Social Sciences Select this course as a placeholder for a Global Pathway course you plan to take to fulfill the Social Sciences UB Area. Refer to the Global Pathway in the Path Finder tool to view a full listing of course options. Please consult with your academic advisor and study abroad staff after selecting this course. To learn more about how study abroad fits into the Global Pathway, visit http://www.buffalo.edu/studyabroad/learn-about-study-abroad/GlobalPathway.html.Credits: 0Grading Zero Credit Crse No Transcript (ZCR)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring

UE 101LEC - Major and Career Exploration This course is designed to assist entering first-year students who are exploring majors to acquire the necessary skills, information and resources to make informed and timely academic decisions. Through in-class activities, guest speakers and self-reflective homework assignments, students will learn about their various academic and career options. After successfully completing UE 101, students will: Know the resources on campus to help make an informed decision when choosing a major. Increase self-awareness regarding interests, values and academic strengths. Increase knowledge of academic and career options of interest. Understand career decision-making as a process informed by direct experiences and chance events.Credits: 1Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Fall

course: UE 201 - Experiential Learning Network: Sophomore Seminar
description: UE 201SEM - Experiential Learning Network: Sophomore Seminar This 7-week, 1-credit course is designed to help you assess your current skills and areas for growth, explore potential projects and start one that aligns with your goals. At the end of this course, you will be on your way to successfully completing a mentored project and earning a digital badge to display new skills and accomplishments on your resume or portfolio.Credits: 1Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)

UGC 111LR - World Civilizations I UGC 111 is usually completed before UGC 112 . Introduces students to the development of world civilizations from prehistory to about 1500, and concerns the peoples, forces, and ideas that have shaped the way individuals have experienced (and still do experience) the world. Features global perspectives, focuses on the origins and development, geographical context, and the interactions of world cultures. All sections of the course share common goals. Different sections emphasize different themes and perspectives. This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade other than W may repeat the course in the summer or winter; or only in the fall or spring semester with a petition to the College of Arts and Sciences Deans’ Office.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

UGC 112LR - World Civilizations II UGC 112 is usually completed after UGC 111 . Introduces students to the continuing development of world civilizations from about 1500 to the present, and concerns the peoples, forces, and ideas that have shaped the way individuals have experienced (and still do experience) the world. Features global perspectives, focuses on the origins and development, geographical context, and the interactions of world cultures. All sections of the course share common goals. Different sections emphasize different themes and perspectives. This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade other than W may repeat the course in the summer or winter; or only in the fall or spring semester with a petition to the College of Arts and Sciences Deans’ Office.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

UGC 198SEM - UB Seminar The one credit UB Seminar is focused on a big idea or challenging issue to engage students with questions of significance in a field of study and, ultimately, to connect their studies with issues of consequence in the wider world. Essential to the UB Curriculum, the Seminar helps transition to UB through an early connection to UB faculty and the undergraduate experience at a comprehensive, research university. This course is equivalent to any 198 offered in any subject. This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade of F or R may not be able to repeat the course during the fall or spring semester.Credits: 1Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SpringRequisites: Students who have already successfully completed the UB seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor.

UGC 199SEM - UB Seminar The three credit UB Seminar is focused on a big idea or challenging issue to engage students with questions of significance in a field of study and, ultimately, to connect their studies with issues of consequence in the wider world. Essential to the UB Curriculum, the Seminar helps students with common learning outcomes focused on fundamental expectations for critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and oral communication, and learning at a university, all within topic focused subject matter. The Seminars provide students with an early connection to UB faculty and the undergraduate experience at a comprehensive, research university. This course is equivalent to any 199 offered in any subject. This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade of F or R may not be able to repeat the course during the fall or spring semester.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SpringRequisites: Students who have already successfully completed the first year seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor.

course: UGC 211 - American Pluralism and the Search for Equality
description: UGC 211LEC - American Pluralism and the Search for Equality UGC 211 is usually completed after UGC 111  - UGC 112 . Focuses on the changing nature of American society, examining the rich diversity of cultural experiences in America and issues associated with diversity. Introduces students to five important areas of American experience and culture: race, gender, ethnicity, class, and religious sectarianism. Examines writings by and about Americans of color; women; and people from diverse ethnic, class, and religious groups. Approaches their experiences through a number of traditional academic disciplines.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

course: UGC 302 - Great Discoveries in Science: The Microworld
description: UGC 302LEC - Great Discoveries in Science: The Microworld The Microworld focuses on experimental studies of microscopic phenomena, including such areas as quantum theory, molecular theory, DNA, etc. UGC 302 and UGC 303  focus upon selected great discoveries of science, presenting a particular body of scientific facts and concepts and connecting them with the process of science, related history and philosophy, and the interdependence of science and technology. These courses engage non-science students in a meaningful analysis of scientific developments and methodology, building on the student’s prior knowledge of science, social science, arts and literature. These courses emphasize the central ideas that set the framework for a discipline and its great discoveries. Selected examples from diverse fields provide a breadth that complements the depth offered in the prerequisite introductory-level science course. The course focus varies by section. Coverage may include the biology of women, microbiology in our daily lives, the solar system, or medical implant controversies. Whether the matters be medical, environmental, or issues of national defense, students must be able to sort fact from fantasy, accident from design, research from quackery. They must feel secure enough in the world of science to participate in those decisions which will determine the quality of their lives, and that of their world. Either UGC 302 or UGC 303  meets the general education Depth requirement.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

course: UGC 303 - Great Discoveries in Science: The Macroworld
description: UGC 303LEC - Great Discoveries in Science: The Macroworld The Macroworld involves larger and longer-term phenomena such as evolution, plate tectonics, astrophysics, etc. UGC 302  and UGC 303 focus upon selected great discoveries of science, presenting a particular body of scientific facts and concepts and connecting them with the process of science, related history and philosophy, and the interdependence of science and technology. These courses engage non-science students in a meaningful analysis of scientific developments and methodology, building on the student’s prior knowledge of science, social science, arts and literature. These courses emphasize the central ideas that set the framework for a discipline and its great discoveries. Selected examples from diverse fields provide a breadth that complements the depth offered in the prerequisite introductory-level science course. The course focus varies by section. Coverage may include the biology of women, microbiology in our daily lives, the solar system, or medical implant controversies. Whether the matters be medical, environmental, or issues of national defense, students must be able to sort fact from fantasy, accident from design, research from quackery. They must feel secure enough in the world of science to participate in those decisions which will determine the quality of their lives, and that of their world. Either UGC 302  or UGC 303 meets the general education Depth requirement.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

NSG 198SEM - UB Seminar The one credit UB Seminar is focused on a big idea or challenging issue to engage students with questions of significance in a field of study and, ultimately, to connect their studies with issues of consequence in the wider world. Essential to the UB Curriculum, the Seminar helps transition to UB through an early connection to UB faculty and the undergraduate experience at a comprehensive, research university. This course is equivalent to any 198 offered in any subject. This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade of F or R may not be able to repeat the course during the fall or spring semester.Credits: 1Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SummerRequisites: Students who have already successfully completed the UB seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor.

NSG 199SEM - UB Seminar The three credit UB Seminar is focused on a big idea or challenging issue to engage students with questions of significance in a field of study and, ultimately, to connect their studies with issues of consequence in the wider world. Essential to the UB Curriculum, the Seminar helps students with common learning outcomes focused on fundamental expectations for critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and oral communication, and learning at a university, all within topic focused subject matter. The Seminars provide students with an early connection to UB faculty and the undergraduate experience at a comprehensive, research university. This course is equivalent to any 199 offered in any subject. This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade of F or R may not be able to repeat the course during the fall or spring semester.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Students who have already successfully completed the first year seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor.

NSG 250LEC - Human Growth and Development Examines selected physiological and psychosocial factors that influence and characterize human growth and development throughout the life span. Includes lecture/discussion and class participation activities.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring

NSG 295LEC - Statistics for Health Care This course provides a foundation in elementary statistics essential to read, understand, and apply evidence-based health care literature. Concepts of measurement, measurement reliability, sampling methods, and common statistical analysis will be examined. An understanding of course concepts will be developed through an examination of selected evidence-based health care literature.Credits: 4Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

course: NSG 309 - Health Assessment: Concepts and Skills
description: NSG 309LLR - Health Assessment: Concepts and Skills Prepares students to perform a health assessment on an adult and child. Emphasizes a systematic and comprehensive health assessment as a database for identifying nursing diagnoses. Highlights developmental aspects, sociocultural influences, health-illness perceptions, normal variations of health-status findings, and documentation throughout the course. Students become familiar with the use of assessment instruments through practice in a supervised on-campus laboratory. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 4Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: NUR 309 Co-Requisites: NUR 370, NUR 371, NUR 373.

course: NSG 310 - Health Promotion and Disease Prevention in Professional Nursing Practice Across the Lifespan
description: NSG 310LEC - Health Promotion and Disease Prevention in Professional Nursing Practice Across the Lifespan This course focuses on health promotion and disease prevention for individuals and families. Students will apply the nursing process to promote holistic health across the lifespan using evidence to critically examine and identify influences on health and well-being. Students will analyze national health indicators, situational and contextual issues that impact wellness and group functioning that serve as a basis for identifying the needs and disparities in health and wellness.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisites: Admission to Nursing program.

NSG 311LEC - Family Nursing Focuses on family and group dynamics, and the application of the nursing process to promote holistic family health across the lifespan. Explores situational and contextual issues that impact family and group functioning. Discusses key issues related to crisis intervention with families and groups and the family’s presence during critical experiences of health care. Identifies the imperative need for ongoing research on caring for families and groups by nurses. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 2Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-requisite: Admission to the Nursing Program

course: NSG 312 - Science of Professional Nursing Practice
description: NSG 312LEC - Science of Professional Nursing Practice This foundational nursing course enables students to develop an understanding of the science of professional nursing using the Scope and Standards of Nursing Practice and Code of Ethics as a framework for the professional nursing role. Students are introduced to the role of the nurse in interprofessional collaborative practice that promotes wellness, manages illness and achieves quality and safety outcomes. Through the application and understanding of critical thinking, clinical reasoning, and predictive management, students are prepared to become situational thinkers to provide evidence-based, culturally relevant, patient-centered care across the lifespan.Credits: 5Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisites: Admission to Nursing program and Co-Req NSG 313 .

course: NSG 313 - Science of Professional Nursing Practice Practicum
description: NSG 313LAB - Science of Professional Nursing Practice Practicum The practicum provides an opportunity to apply the science of nursing to the provision of holistic, culturally relevant, evidence-based, patient-centered care for patients, families, and populations across the lifespan. Students will apply the science of nursing, as they become situational thinkers and predictive managers of care.Credits: 4Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisites: Admission to Nursing program; Co-Req NSG 312 .

course: NSG 314 - Application of Healthcare Informatics to Promote Health, Quality and Safety
description: NSG 314LEC - Application of Healthcare Informatics to Promote Health, Quality and Safety This course builds upon communication literacy concepts through application of computer and information technology that impacts nursing practice. The use of information management systems is explored in relationship to interprofessional communication, management of data to inform knowledge, prevent and mitigate error, and support decision-making. Emphasis is placed on monitoring trends in practice and in outcomes of care. Students are introduced to research and evidence-based practice standards in information systems to improve cost-effectiveness, safety, and quality.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisites: Admission to the Nursing program.

course: NSG 315 - Social Determinants and Justice in Local and Global Settings
description: NSG 315LEC - Social Determinants and Justice in Local and Global Settings This course examines the cultural, political, economic, educational, environmental and health systems that impact healthcare in local, regional and global populations. Concepts of public health, epidemiology and community assessment will support a primary prevention and wellness focus. The value of relationships and collaborative practice for understanding and addressing community-identified needs, increasing inclusivity and diversity, and for strengthening community assets will be explored. Students will advocate for populations using health promotion, educational, and community empowerment strategies.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Spring, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisites: NSG 310  and NSG 314

course: NSG 316 - Wellness and Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities I
description: NSG 316LEC - Wellness and Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities I This course promotes wellness and a healthier lifestyle for individuals, families and populations, across the wellness-illness continuum. Selected concepts and exemplars provide a foundation for the development of conceptual thinking and skills to facilitate clinical reasoning. Through the application and understanding of critical thinking, clinical reasoning, and predictive management, students will use situational thinking to provide evidence-based, culturally relevant, patient-centered collaborative care across the lifespan.Credits: 5Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Spring, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisites: NSG 310 , NSG 312 , NSG 313 , NSG 314 ; Co-Req NSG 317

course: NSG 317 - Wellness & Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities I - Practicum
description: NSG 317LAB - Wellness & Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities I - Practicum The practicum provides an opportunity to promote wellness and a healthier lifestyle for individuals, families and populations, across the wellness-illness continuum. Students will apply critical thinking, clinical reasoning, and predictive management; using situational thinking to provide evidence-based, culturally relevant, patient-centered collaborative care across the lifespan in clinical settings.Credits: 4Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Spring, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisites: NSG 310 , NSG 312 , NSG 313 , NSG 314 ; Co-Req NSG 316

course: NSG 348 - Evidence Based Practice and Nursing Research
description: NSG 348LEC - Evidence Based Practice and Nursing Research Foundations for evidence-based practice in nursing. Specific elements of evidence-based practice include formulating the clinical question, conducting a search strategy, critically appraising the evidence, and implementation of evidence in the clinical environment. Basic concepts of the research process will form the foundation for assessing the quality of evidence. Explores the relationship between evidence-based findings and nursing practice to achieve favorable and cost-containing client outcomes. Must be taken in program sequence. This course is equivalent to NBC 348 .Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SpringRequisites: Pre-Requisite: Sophomore standing. NSG 295  or PSY 207  or STA 119  and STA 119  or SSC 225  or CEP 207 . Completion of Communication Literacy 1 or completion of Writing Skills 1 (ENG 101 or placement into ENG 201); Admission to the Nursing Program.

course: NSG 350 - Building Competence for Community Engagement Across Populations
description: NSG 350LAB - Building Competence for Community Engagement Across Populations This course will provide students an opportunity to integrate academic study with community engagement. Seminar participation and experiential learning will foster the development of cultural sensitivity, civic engagement, advocacy, collaborative practice, ethical decision making and social responsibility. Experiential learning can occur across populations and can include urban, rural, and global settings. The global health international experience will be processed through the UB Study Abroad and will incur and additional cost.Credits: 2Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer, WinterRequisites: NUR Upper Division Prerequisite: Admission to the Nursing Program

NSG 368LEC - Research in Human Sexuality Elective open to non-nursing students. Focuses on current research on human sexual behavior, including physiological response during sexual activity, early development of sexual attitudes, varieties of sexual relationships, and social/moral issues related to sexual attitudes.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Spring

NSG 370LEC - Nursing As a Profession Explores the evolution, current status, characteristics, and future directions of professional nursing and analyses the foundations of modern nursing. Discusses relationships between historical events and evolving nursing science, theory, and practice. Information seeking methodologies are analyzed with emphasis placed on critical thinking as an approach to making professional decisions. Highlights concepts related to critical thinking, development and critique of persuasive arguments, current issues in nursing, and small group communication. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SummerRequisites: Pre-Requisite: Admission to the Nursing Program.NUR 370 Co-Requisite: NUR 309, NUR 371, NUR 373.

NSG 371LEC - Basic Nursing Therapeutics Foundational nursing course; enables students to begin developing an understanding of the professional nursing role. Core nursing concepts, (caring, compassion, wellness, health promotion, disease prevention, therapeutic use of self) are integrated as the student learns about the complex nature of providing nursing care of individuals and their families. Must be taken in program sequence. NSG 373  must be taken concurrently.Credits: 4Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, SummerRequisites: NSG 371 Pre-Requisite: Admission to the Nursing Program.NSG 371 Corequisites: NSG 309 , NSG 370 , NSG 373

NSG 373LAB - Basic Nursing Therapeutics Practicum This is a basic nursing therapeutics practicum course which provides laboratory, simulation and clinical practicum opportunities to provide holistic, patient centered care using the nursing process and evidenced based practice concepts. The students will begin to develop and acquire clinical reasoning skills as they learn to provide nursing care to assist individuals and families in achieving optimal health. Students begin to organize and manage nursing care to achieve safe and quality health outcomes.Credits: 2Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-Requisite: Admission to the Nursing Program.NSG 373 Corequisites: NSG 309 , NSG 370 , NSG 371

course: NSG 374 - Nursing Care Wmn and Child
description: NSG 374LEC - Nursing Care Wmn and Child Describes the characteristics of primary health care and its delivery. Examines the nurse’s role in delivery of primary health/community-based services focusing on health promotion, disease prevention, and management of episodic illness. Addresses health risks of age groups across the life span within the context of family, culture, and socioeconomic level. Healthy People Goals and other national initiatives provide direction for developing strategies. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 5Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Spring, Summer

course: NSG 375 - Nursing Care of Women and Children Practicum
description: NSG 375LAB - Nursing Care of Women and Children Practicum Credits: 4Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Spring, Summer

course: NSG 393 - Informatics and the Health Care Environment
description: NSG 393SEM - Informatics and the Health Care Environment Introduces students to the health care environment emphasizing the interface between the health care delivery system and informatics. Explores various environments where people obtain health care, including clinics, hospitals, and community settings. Students become familiar with health care terminology, government health policies, and the influence of managed care organizations on the health care environment.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, SummerRequisites: NUR Upper Division Prerequisite: Admission to the Nursing Program

course: NSG 409 - Ethics for the Health Professions
description: NSG 409SEM - Ethics for the Health Professions This course prepares undergraduate students to identify and address multiple ethical issues arising within professional practice and the dynamic health care delivery system. With the use of ethical theories and principles the student will apply ethical decision making models to address dilemmas within practice, health care systems, and global communities. This course is designed to provide strategies for promoting ethical practice and developing ethical leadership within the technological health care environment.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Spring

course: NSG 410 - Public Health Nursing for Population Health
description: NSG 410LEC - Public Health Nursing for Population Health This course explores concepts of public health and principles of population health within the context of the interdisciplinary public health system domestically and globally. Core functions of public health, principles of epidemiology, and public health nursing interventions will be used to examine population health problems and concerns. The use of evidence-based interventions and theories of behavior change will be analyzed as strategies to improve cost, access, and quality of population health. Within the public health nurse?s role, the use of risk communication, informatics, and social interventions to implement public health laws, policies to effect change in population health will be explored. Public health disaster preparedness and response to natural disasters and terrorist threats will be emphasized.Credits: 2Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 311 , NSG 374 , NSG 375 .Co-Requisite: NSG 470 , NSG 474 .

course: NSG 411 - Wellness and Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities II
description: NSG 411LEC - Wellness and Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities II This course builds on the foundation of Wellness and Illness I, expanding student?s abilities to promote wellness and a healthier lifestyle for individuals, families and populations, across the wellness-illness continuum. Selected concepts and exemplars provide for further development of conceptual thinking and skills to facilitate clinical reasoning. Through the application and understanding of critical thinking, clinical reasoning, and predictive management, students will continue to broaden their situational thinking abilities to provide evidence-based, culturally relevant, patient-centered collaborative care across the lifespan.Credits: 5Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 315  and NSG 316  and NSG 317  and NSG 348 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 412 .

course: NSG 412 - Wellness & Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families, and Communities II - Practicum
description: NSG 412LAB - Wellness & Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families, and Communities II - Practicum This course builds on the foundation of Wellness and Illness I Practicum, providing an opportunity to promote wellness and a healthier lifestyle for individuals, families and populations, across the wellness-illness continuum in varying health care settings. Students will apply critical thinking, clinical reasoning, and predictive management; using situational thinking to provide evidence-based, culturally relevant, patient-centered collaborative care across the lifespan in professional practice.Credits: 4Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 315  and NSG 316  and NSG 317  and NSG 348 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 411 .

course: NSG 413 - Promoting Quality Health Outcomes in a Culture of Safety
description: NSG 413LEC - Promoting Quality Health Outcomes in a Culture of Safety This course examines concepts of quality health outcomes and safety within the context of professional nursing practice. Systems and processes are explored and analyzed to promote and sustain quality health outcomes, and safe, effective healthcare environments. Focus is placed on the role the professional nurse as leader in a collaborative practice in a patient- centered, evidence- based culture of safety.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 315  and NSG 348 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 414 .

course: NSG 414 - Health Systems Policy and Economics
description: NSG 414LEC - Health Systems Policy and Economics This course examines the policy and politics involved in the access, cost and quality of healthcare. Students will address economic considerations faced by institutions and key stakeholders. The role of the nurse as a member of the interprofessional team, within the context of the complex healthcare environment, is explored.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Requisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 348  and NSG 315 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 413 .

course: NSG 415 - Wellness and Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities III
description: NSG 415LEC - Wellness and Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities III This course builds on the foundation of Wellness and Illness I and II, preparing students to transition into professional practice as a member of the interprofessional team. Students will expand their abilities to recognize evolving situations for individuals, families and populations across the lifespan. Focus is placed on synthesizing and analyzing the meaning of assessment findings and relevant data, connecting this information to previous knowledge and experiences to prioritize care and promote quality and safe outcomes.Credits: 4Grading Graded (GRD)Requisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 411  and NSG 412  and NSG 413  and NSG 414 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 416 .

course: NSG 416 - Wellness & Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities III - Practicum
description: NSG 416LAB - Wellness & Illness Concepts with Individuals, Families and Communities III - Practicum This course builds on the foundation of Wellness and Illness I and II Practicum, preparing students for the complexities of practice as they transition into professional practice as a member of the interprofessional team. Students will recognize evolving situations for individuals, families and populations across the lifespan. Students will synthesize and analyze assessment findings and relevant trending data, connecting this information to previous knowledge and experiences to prioritize care and promote quality and safe outcomes.Credits: 5Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: SpringRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 411  and NSG 412  and NSG 413  and NSG 414 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 415 .

course: NSG 417 - Leading Professional Nursing Practice to Achieve Quality Outcomes
description: NSG 417LEC - Leading Professional Nursing Practice to Achieve Quality Outcomes The purpose of this course is to prepare the baccalaureate nursing student for transition to professional nursing practice as a leader from the bedside to the boardroom. Emphasis is placed on guiding decisions and collaborative practice through the use of ethical decision-making. Students will be prepared to enter practice with the ability to identify, plan, and implement evidence-based strategies to improve quality, safety, and patient outcomes across diverse populations.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: SpringRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 413  and NSG 414 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 418 .

course: NSG 418 - Care Transitions and Care Coordination
description: NSG 418LEC - Care Transitions and Care Coordination This course explores the role of the professional nurse in care coordination to transform healthcare, initiating at the bedside and extending to transition in care. Relationships between health information technology; collaboration; care coordination; and evidence-based, patient-centered care are examined as central forces that impact health outcomes across populations and systems. Focus is placed on developing students? abilities to participate in care management of healthcare consumers in a variety of healthcare settings to maximize their independence and quality of life.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: SpringRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 413  and NSG 414 ; Co-Requisite: NSG 417  and NSG 415  and NSG 416 .

NSG 447LAB - Advanced Clinical Nursing Clinical course that provides students opportunities to pursue, independently and in depth, a specific nursing area of particular interest. Expects ongoing student, faculty, and preceptor collaboration. Students participate in selecting the site for clinical experience. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 3Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: SpringRequisites: NUR Upper Division Prerequisite: Admission to the Nursing Program

NSG 470LEC - Health Maintenance and Restoration Covers goals of health maintenance and restoration for individuals with acute and chronic illness. Presents major physical and mental illnesses and disabilities across the life span through exemplar case studies that deal with nursing interventions related to functional health, homeostatic regulation, protection against harm, and psychological function. Also examines effective use of the health-care system. Must be taken in program sequence. NUR 470 L must be taken concurrently.Credits: 4Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-Requisite:NSG 372, NSG 374 , NSG 375 , and NSG 378.Co-Requisite: NSG 410 , NSG 474 .

course: NSG 472 - Promoting Quality Health Outcomes and Culture of Safety
description: NSG 472LEC - Promoting Quality Health Outcomes and Culture of Safety Examines nursing management skills and behaviors with applicability in a wide variety of client-care settings. Emphasizes organizational structure and behavior, applying information management and case-management techniques to the management of care for groups of clients, and applying principles of delegation, supervision, and personnel evaluation to management of care provided by others. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 2Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall

course: NSG 474 - Nursing Therapeutics in Health Maintenance and Restoration
description: NSG 474LAB - Nursing Therapeutics in Health Maintenance and Restoration Covers goals of health maintenance and restoration for individuals with acute and chronic illness. Presents major physical and mental illnesses and disabilities across the life span through exemplar case studies that deal with nursing interventions related to functional health, homeostatic regulation, protection against harm, and psychological function. Also examines effective use of the health-care system. Must be taken in program sequence. NUR 470 L must be taken concurrently.Credits: 4Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: FallRequisites: Pre-Requisite:NSG 372, NSG 374 , NSG 375  , and NSG 378.Co-Requisite: NSG 410 , NSG 474.

course: NSG 475 - Transitioning to Professional Nursing Practice as a Leader/Manager
description: NSG 475LEC - Transitioning to Professional Nursing Practice as a Leader/Manager Prepares the baccalaureate nursing student for transition to professional nursing practice as a leader/manager. Discusses organizational structures and processes of heath care organizations as context for professional nursing practice. Analyzes the collaborative roles of the nurse as leader and manager within the framework of legislative, economic, and regulated health care environments. Explores the legal and ethical parameters which influence the role of the nurse as leader/manager. A personal career plan is developed that incorporates strategies and processes for successful transition and practice.Credits: 2Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: SpringRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 410 , NSG 470 , NSG 474 .Co-Requisite: NSG 478 , NSG 479 , NSG 481 .

course: NSG 478 - Concepts of Complex Acute Care
description: NSG 478LEC - Concepts of Complex Acute Care Reviews knowledge and skills required to care for patients throughout their life spans who have complex, life-threatening health problems, including trauma, problems with oxygenation, disruptions of the nervous system, and disruption of the immune system. Emphasizes assessment skills and nursing interventions to restore physiological and psychological stability. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 4Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: SpringRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 410 , NSG 470 , NSG 474 . Co-Requisite: NSG 475 , NSG 481 , NSG 479 .

course: NSG 479 - Clinical Seminar: Complex Acute Care
description: NSG 479SEM - Clinical Seminar: Complex Acute Care Content derived from clinical situations encountered in NSG 478  Nursing Therapeutics in Complex Acute Care. Students share clinical reports and raise critical questions regarding practice issues and propose and evaluate responses. Issues focus on direct care, health-system concerns, and professional interactions at both the client and system levels. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 1Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Spring

course: NSG 481 - Nursing Management of Patients with Complex Acute Health Care Problems
description: NSG 481LAB - Nursing Management of Patients with Complex Acute Health Care Problems Reviews knowledge and skills required to care for patients throughout their life spans who have complex, life-threatening health problems, including trauma, problems with oxygenation, disruptions of the nervous system, and disruption of the immune system. Emphasizes assessment skills and nursing interventions to restore physiological and psychological stability. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 4Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: SpringRequisites: Pre-Requisite: NSG 410 , NSG 470 , NSG 474 . Co-Requisite: NSG 475 , NSG 481, NSG 479 .

NSG 495TUT - Supervised Teaching Outstanding undergraduate students can enrich their education and gain personal recognition through participation in a supervised teaching experience with a Nursing faculty member. In concert with the faculty member, student teachers will have an opportunity to develop their leadership, management, teaching, technology, and presentation skills in a course previously completed.Credits: 1-3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

NSG 496TUT - Issues in Clinical Practice Accompanies a summer clinical experience in which students provide patient care at a health-care agency in the Buffalo area. Focus of discussions is on issues that arise out of patient care and the clinical setting such as communication, clinical skills, interactions with colleagues, and documentation of care that is provided. Must be taken in program sequence.Credits: 1Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

NSG 497TUT - Nursing Honors Research Students accepted into the School of Nursing Honors Research program must complete this course twice, during both semesters of the senior year. It will provide an opportunity for outstanding undergraduate nursing students to enrich their education and gain personal recognition through participation in the scholarly work of a research faculty member. In concert with a faculty member, the student will conduct a research project that culminates into a senior thesis of publication quality.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring

NSG 499TUT - Independent Study Supplements regular offerings of the department. Students must secure the instructor’s permission before registering for an independent study.Credits: 1-4Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

UBE 102SEM - Dynamics of Leadership For a student at the beginning of his/her leadership journey. Presents the fundamentals of leadership while allowing time for self awareness and discovery. Explores and defines different aspects of leadership, leaders on campus, and leadership in action, while making it clear that leadership is not just a position. Designed to develop leaders through an interactive group experience and require each student to be an active participant.Credits: 1Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring

UBE 110SEM - Introduction to Peer Education Prepares students for a peer education experience. Provides the skills necessary to play a role as a peer educator, a resident advisor, or a leader of a club or organization.Credits: 2Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring

UBE 202LEC - Career Planning Assists students in examining their major/career choice. Focuses on career awareness, personal awareness, and educational awareness as they relate to the process of making a career decision. Discusses planning skills and incorporates self-assessment instruments that help inform tentative career options. Also explores decision-making strategies, and the creation of goals and action plans.Credits: 2Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Fall, Spring

UBE 302LEC - College to Career Examines the components of managing a successful job/internship search by focusing on goal setting, identification of transferable skills, professional branding and integration of effective search techniques. Self-assessment instruments, planning and research skills will be cultivated to help generate career paths and facilitate the transition to the world of work. Special attention will be given to writing effective resumes/cover letters, developing interviewing skills, interacting directly with employers and utilizing a creative and proactive approach to generate opportunities.Credits: 1Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)Typically Offered: Winter

UBE 496TUT - Internship/Practicum Students increase their understanding of particular areas of interest including leadership, diversity, health and wellness, career planning, and more through educational and work experience in various Student Affairs offices.Credits: 1-3Grading Pass/Not Pass (PNP)

VS 220LEC - Topics in Visual Studies A course that explores different aspects of visual culture, which focuses on a different subject each semester that it is offered. Explores both the visual qualities and the critical analysis of a particular aspect of current and historical visual study.Credits: 3Grading Graded (GRD)Typically Offered: Spring
